form.steps:
1. Adjust a weight bench to a decline angle, typically between 15-30 degrees. 
2. Lie down on the bench with your feet flat on the floor or secured under the foot pads. 
3. Hold a dumbbell in each hand, with an overhand grip, slightly wider than shoulder-width apart. 
4. Lower the dumbbells slowly towards your chest, keeping your elbows slightly bent and tucked in at a 45-degree angle. 
5. Once the dumbbells reach chest level, pause for a moment. 
6. Press the dumbbells back up to the starting position, extending your arms fully without locking your elbows.

form.Grip: Overhand grip, slightly wider than shoulder-width apart.
form.Elbows: Keep your elbows slightly bent and tucked in at a 45-degree angle.
form.Back: Maintain a slight arch in your back throughout the exercise.
form.Feet: Keep your feet flat on the floor or secured under the foot pads.
form.Chest: Lower the dumbbells until they touch your lower chest, slightly below your nipples.

commonMistakes.Lowering dumbbells too quickly: Lowering the dumbbells too quickly can put excessive stress on your shoulder joints.
commonMistakes.Bouncing the dumbbells off your chest: This can lead to injury and reduces muscle activation.
commonMistakes.Flaring elbows: Flaring your elbows outwards can strain your shoulder joints. Keep them slightly tucked in.
commonMistakes.Lifting your hips: Keep your hips down on the bench throughout the exercise. Lifting them indicates improper form and reduces effectiveness.
commonMistakes.Holding your breath: Remember to breathe throughout the exercise. Inhale as you lower the dumbbells and exhale as you press them up.

comments.Muscle activation: The decline dumbbell chest press primarily targets the lower chest muscles, more than the flat or incline variations. It also engages the anterior deltoids and triceps.
comments.Range of motion: Using dumbbells allows for a greater range of motion compared to using a barbell, potentially leading to increased muscle activation.
comments.Stabilization: The use of dumbbells requires more stabilization from the shoulder and core muscles, which can be beneficial for overall upper body strength and stability.
comments.Progressive overload: As you get stronger, gradually increase the weight of the dumbbells to continue challenging your muscles.

alternativesAndVariations.Barbell decline chest press: This variation uses a barbell instead of dumbbells, which can allow for heavier weight but reduces the range of motion.
alternativesAndVariations.Decline dumbbell flyes: This exercise focuses more on the pecs and provides a greater stretch at the bottom of the movement.
alternativesAndVariations.Decline push-ups: A bodyweight alternative that can be done with your feet elevated on a bench.
alternativesAndVariations.Cable crossovers (low-to-high): This variation targets the lower chest from a different angle, providing a unique stimulus.

dumbbell-decline-chest-press.tempo: 3011 (3 seconds lowering, 0 seconds pause at the bottom, 1 second lifting, 1 second pause at the top)
